titleStmt.title: Monocytes Promote Crescent Formation in Anti-Myeloperoxidase AntibodyeInduced Glomerulonephritis

analytic.title: Monocytes Promote Crescent Formation in Anti-Myeloperoxidase AntibodyeInduced Glomerulonephritis

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Neutrophils and monocytes express anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) antigens, and activation of these cells by ANCA is central to ANCA-associated vasculitis and necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis (NCGN).
The importance of neutrophils is established; however, any role of monocytes is less clear.
We tested the hypothesis that depletion of CCR2 þ inflammatory monocytes and their derivatives would abrogate anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO) antibodyeinduced NCGN in a mouse model.
We used passive anti-MPO antibody transfer for NCGN induction in wild-type mice or mice expressing the CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor.
Both mouse strains showed similar circulating Ly6C hi and Ly6C lo monocytes and neutrophils at baseline.
Diphtheria toxin robustly depleted circulating monocytes only in CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor mice, whereas neutrophil numbers were similar.
Anti-MPO antibody transfer resulted in nephritic urine by dipstick and albuminuria by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and monocyte depletion had no effect.

However, monocyte depletion significantly reduced glomerular necrosis and crescent formation and abrogated monocyte, macrophage, and dendritic cell increase in the affected kidneys, whereas renal neutrophil numbers were not affected.
Soluble CD163 increased in serum, but not in urine, with anti-MPO antibody treatment and was completely abolished with monocyte depletion.
Our findings establish an important role of monocytes/macrophages for glomerular necrosis and crescent formation in a renal ANCAassociated vasculitis model.
work used the passive anti-MPO antibody transfer model to test the hypothesis that the other ANCA antigeneexpressing cell (namely, the monocyte) is essential for NCGN.
Monocytes are grouped into subsets according to chemokine receptor and Ly6C expression in mice and CD14 and CD16 expression in humans.
Classic inflammatory murine monocytes are CCR2 þ Ly6C hi , whereas nonclassic monocytes are CCR2 À Ly6C lo .

Diphteria toxin (DT) was obtained from List Biological Laboratories (Campbell, CA), lipopolysaccharides (LPSs) (Escherichia coli, serotype 026:B6), liberase, and DNase were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany), urine dipsticks were purchased from Roche Diagnostics (Indianapolis, IN), and phosphate-buffered saline without Mg 2þ and Ca 2þ was purchased from Biochrom (Berlin, Germany).
Rat anti-mouse Gr-1 (clone RB6-8C5) was from BD Biosciences (Heidelberg, Germany), and rat anti-mouse CD68 (clone FA-11) was from Bio-Rad (Munich, Germany).
Horseradish peroxidaseelabeled rabbit anti-rat IgG and goat anti-rabbit IgG antibodies were obtained from Dako (Glostrup, Denmark).

div.head: Animals, Immunization, and Purification of Anti-MPO IgG

p.s: Mice were kept under specific pathogen-free conditions at the Max Delbrück Center for Molecular Medicine (Berlin, Germany) animal facility.
All mice were on a C57Bl/6 background.
CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor (CCR2-DTR) mice were kindly provided by Dr. Tobias Hohl (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY).
Mice with one CCR2-DTR transgene copy were used for monocyte depletion, and littermates negative for the CCR2-DTR transgene were used as controls.
Anti-MPO IgG was produced in Mpo À/À mice immunized with murine MPO.
Purification of murine MPO from WEHI-3 cells, immunization of Mpo À/À mice, and isolation of the IgG fraction were performed as previously described. 6
The local authorities (Landesamt für Gesundheit und Soziales, Berlin, Germany) duly approved the experiments.
CCR2-DTR and control [wild-type (WT)] littermates were treated with 3 ng/g body weight (BW) DT i.p. at day -1, followed by 2.5 mg/g BW LPS at day 0 for leukocyte priming.

Four hours after LPS injection, five mice with matching blood neutrophil numbers were selected from both groups for subsequent disease induction with 50 mg/g BW anti-MPO IgG administered by retro-orbital injection.
WT mice without anti-MPO IgG treatment were used as additional controls.
All groups then received 3 ng/g BW DT at days 1, 3, and 5. Mice were sacrificed at day 6.
Mice were placed in metabolic cages with free access to water and food on the day before sacrifice.
Urine was collected over 18 hours.

Urine was tested by dipstick for proteinuria, erythrocyturia, and leukocyturia, and the results were expressed on a scale of 0 (none) to 4 (severe) for erythrocyturia, and of 0 to 3 for proteinuria and leukocyturia, respectively.
Urine albumin concentration was determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Bethyl Laboratories, Inc., Montgomery, TX).
Blood was obtained from the heart before sacrifice, and blood urea nitrogen was measured by the Max Delbrück Center for Molecular Medicine Pathophysiology Platform.
Soluble CD163 levels in urine and serum were measured with mouse CD163 DuoSet ELISA (R&D Systems, Wiesbaden-Nordenstadt, Germany).
Kidney tissue was collected at the time of sacrifice, fixed in 10% formalin for 24 hours, and embedded in paraffin using routine procedures.
Sections (2.5 mm thick) were stained with periodic acideSchiff and observed by light microscopy using an Axio Imager.M2 microscope (Zeiss, Jena, Germany).
The percentage of glomeruli with crescents and necrosis was calculated for each animal.
For leukocyte detection by immunohistology, sections of snapfrozen tissues (5 mm thick) were stained with antibodies for neutrophil Gr-1 (antieGr-1) and for monocyte/macrophage CD68 (anti-CD68).

Rat antibody binding was detected using horseradish peroxidaseelabeled secondary rabbit anti-rat IgG and tertiary goat anti-rabbit IgG antibodies with 3-amino-9-ethylcarbazole and hydrogen peroxide as substrates.
Sections were counterstained with hematoxylin.

div.head: Leukocyte Isolation from Kidneys and Flow Cytometry Analysis

p.s: Kidney biopsy specimens were minced and digested for 50 minutes at 37 C with 0.2 mg/mL liberase and 100 U/mL DNase in phosphate-buffered saline without Mg 2þ and Ca 2þ .
Cell suspensions were then filtered through 70-mm mesh and centrifuged 5 minutes at 500 Â g.
Cells were resuspended in 500 mL phosphate-buffered saline for subsequent staining and flow cytometry.
Fluorochromeconjugated antibodies were used directed to CD45 (30-F11; BD Biosciences), CD11b (M1/70; eBioscience, San Diego, CA), CD8 (53-6.7;
BD Biosciences), Ly6G (1A8), Ly6C (HK1.4),
CD19 (6D5), and NK1.1 (PK136), all from Biolegend (San Diego, CA).
Anti-mouse CD16/32 IgG (Biolegend) was used to block Fc receptors.
Dead cells were excluded using LIVE/DEAD Fixable Near-IR Dead Cell Stain Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Rockford, IL).
Red blood cell lysis was performed with ammonium chloride.
All cell populations were gated as live CD45 þ cells after exclusion of doublets and further characterized with their respective markers.
BD Trucount tubes (BD Biosciences) were used to determine absolute number of blood and kidney leukocyte subsets (normalized as per mL blood or g kidney, respectively).
Percentages indicated in flow cytometry plots represent the relative frequency of a cell population in the respective active gate.
Samples were acquired using an FACS CANTO II flow cytometer with BD FACSDiva software version 6.1.2
(BD Biosciences).
Data were analyzed using FlowJo software version 10 (Treestar, Ashland, OR).
Results were expressed as means AE SEM.
All statistical analyses were performed with the GraphPad Prism 5 software (GraphPad Software, Inc., La Jolla, CA).
A t-test was used for comparison between two groups, and one-way analysis of variance with Bonferroni test was used for multiple comparisons.
P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

div.head: Results

p.s: We capitalized on a transgenic mouse strain that expressed the human diphtheria toxin receptor under the control of the CCR2 promoter (CCR2-DTR), allowing complete depletion of classic CCR2 þ Ly6C hi inflammatory monocytes and their derivatives by human DT. 23
Flow cytometry found no hours after first diphtheria toxin (DT), and 4 hours after LPS, but before anti-MPO (a-MPO) IgG treatment, and at 6 days after administration of a-MPO IgG, respectively.

A: Gating strategy started with CD45 þ leukocytes and characterized blood neutrophils as CD11b þ Ly6G þ cells (top row) and blood monocytes as CD11b þ LyG À CD115 þ with further separation into Ly6C hi and Ly6C lo subsets (bottom row).
The relative frequency of neutrophil was expressed as percentage of CD45 þ leukocytes, and the Ly6C hi and Ly6C lo monocytes as percentage of CD11b þ Ly6G À leukocytes.
B: Absolute neutrophil and monocyte numbers in WT and CCR2-DTR mice at baseline.
C: The final 7-day study protocol is depicted, including doses and time points of DT, LPS, and a-MPO IgG injections, respectively.
D and E: Absolute blood neutrophil and monocyte numbers in WT and CCR2-DTR mice at day 0 (D) and day 6 (E), respectively.

The three study groups were as follows: WT mice that received DT and LPS, but no a-MPO IgG (WT/no a-MPO), WT mice with DT, LPS, and a-MPO (WT/a-MPO), and DTR mice with DT, LPS, and a-MPO (CCR2-DTR/a-MPO), respectively.
Statistical significance between two groups was tested using t-test, and between three groups by one-way analysis of variance with Bonferroni multiple comparison test.
Data are expressed as means AE SEM.
n Z 8 or 9 mice for each group (A).
BW, body weight; CCR2-DTR, CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor.

-The American Journal of Pathology

div.formula: difference in circulating neutrophil (CD11b þ Ly6G þ ) and monocyte numbers (CD11b þ CD115 þ Ly6C hi and CD11b þ CD115 þ Ly6C lo )

p.s: between WT and CCR2-DTR mice at baseline (Figure 1, A and B).
Optimal DT dose and application intervals were established by experiments showing efficient Ly6C þ cell depletion up to 48 hours with DT at 3 ng/g BW (Supplemental Figure S1A).
Our final protocol with repetitive DT injection every 48 hours resulted in reliable depletion of circulating monocytes over 7 days.
A schematic with the DT, LPS, and anti-MPO antibody injections indicated is depicted (Figure 1C).
Blood samples were assessed 20 hours after the first DT dose and 4 hours after subsequent LPS priming for neutrophils and monocytes in WT and CCR2-DTR mice, respectively (Figure 1D).
Mice from both groups had similar blood neutrophil numbers, whereas only CCR2-DTR mice showed effective depletion of circulating Ly6C hi and Ly6C lo monocytes.
In CCR2-DTR mice, the DTR-AmCyan tag is coexpressed with the CCR2 receptor and indicates cells that were directly depleted by DT.
Ly6C hi , but not Ly6C lo , monocytes strongly expressed the tag, indicating that the former, but not the latter, were directly depleted by DT (Supplemental Figure S1B).
However, Ly6C lo monocyte depletion was sufficiently explained by the fact that these cells are derived from Ly6C hi monocytes. 24,25

ssibly, a minor subset of circulating CD4 þ T cells and natural killer cells were also directly depleted by DT because a small percentage of these cells stained positive for the AmCyan tag 24 hours after LPS administration (Supplemental Figure S1C).
Not surprisingly, circulating neutrophil and monocyte numbers were reduced 4 hours after LPS treatment, possibly because of transient endothelial margination.
Blood neutrophil variation between mice, irrespective of the study group, was observed.
To exclude that neutrophil variability would affect our results, five mice with matching neutrophil numbers from each group were selected for subsequent treatment with anti-MPO IgG.
An additional WT group that received DT and LPS, but no anti-MPO IgG (WT/no a-MPO), was included for comparison.

Group analyses at day 6 revealed that anti-MPO antibody treatment increased circulating neutrophil and monocyte numbers and that circulating Ly6C hi and Ly6C lo monocytes were still effectively depleted in CCR2-DTR/a-MPO mice (Figure 1E).
More important, circulating neutrophils were similar in both groups.
One mouse in the CCR2-DTR/a-MPO group had died during the study and could not be analyzed.
Final analyses were performed 6 days after anti-MPO antibody transfer.
Urine analysis by dipstick and albuminuria by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Figure 2, A and B) revealed that WT/no a-MPO mice developed low levels of albuminuria.
In contrast, all mice that received anti-MPO antibodies developed significant proteinuria, leukocyturia, erythrocyturia, and albuminuria.
More important, monocyte depletion did not diminish these urine abnormalities.
Blood urea nitrogen increased nonsignificantly in WT/a-MPO mice but was prevented by monocyte depletion (Figure 2C).
As expected, histological examination of kidney biopsy specimens revealed that WT/ a-MPO mice developed glomerular necrosis and crescent formation (Figure 2, D and E).
In contrast, these glomerular damages were strongly reduced in mice depleted of monocytes.
These results support an important role of monocytes in the development of glomerular necrosis and crescent formation.
Next, we analyzed the cell influx into the kidneys by flow cytometry using characteristic antibody markers and gating strategies.
Anti-MPO antibody treatment increased renal CD11b þ Ly6C hi inflammatory monocytes, CD11b þ F4/80 þ macrophages, and CD11c þ MHCII þ dendritic cells (DCs) in WT mice, respectively.
DT significantly reduced all three cell types in CCR2-DTR/a-MPO mice to, or even below, the level observed in WT/no a-MPO mice (Figure 3A).
In inflammatory conditions, Ly6C hi monocytes infiltrate tissues and differentiate into inflammatory CD11c þ MHCII þ DCs and F4/80 þ macrophages. 26,27
Therefore, the strong reduction of renal DC and macrophage infiltration is sufficiently explained by the depletion of Ly6C hi monocytes.
In contrast, renal neutrophil influx increased with anti-MPO antibody treatment, but was not altered by monocyte depletion (Figure 3B).
CD4 þ T-cell influx also significantly increased with anti-MPO antibody treatment and had a tendency to be reduced with monocyte depletion (Figure 3C).
Immunohistochemistry was performed to visualize the effect of monocyte depletion specifically on glomerular myeloid cell influx.
Both CD68 þ macrophage and Gr-1 þ neutrophil recruitment to glomeruli increased substantially in anti-MPO antibodyetreated WT mice (Figure 4, A and B).
DT administration significantly reduced glomerular macrophages in CCR2-DTR/a-MPO mice, whereas neutrophil numbers were similar when compared to the WT/a-MPO group.
CD163 is expressed on monocytes and macrophages, and a soluble form (sCD163) was recently implicated as a clinical urinary biomarker in patients with active renal ANCA-associated vasculitis. 28
We studied sCD163 in our disease model and observed a strong increase in serum, but not in urine, with anti-MPO IgG treatment (Figure 4C).
Monocyte depletion significantly abolished serum sCD163.

div.head: Discussion

p.s: Our study provides novel experimental in vivo evidence supporting the concept that monocytes are key players in ANCA-associated NCGN.
Different monocyte depletion approaches were reported, such as liposomal clodronate, Ccr2 gene deletion, CD11b-DTR, 27 and recently the use of CCR2-controled DTR mice. 23

We used CCR2-DTR mice because this model allowed complete depletion of highly inflammatory CCR2R þ Ly6C hi monocytes, and we believed that our short-term NCGN model is more suitable for assessing the inflammatory, rather than the regenerative or repair, disease phase.

We achieved effective monocyte/ macrophage depletion, and the most intriguing consequence was the significant reduction of glomerular crescents and necrosis without protecting from nephritic urine and albuminuria.
Conceivably, monocytes/macrophages contribute to crescent formation by several mechanisms, including by IL-1b production. 16,29

nother informative aspect of our study is the effect of CCR2-DTR monocyte depletion on the influx of innate or adaptive immune cells into the kidneys and the potential contribution of these cells to the glomerular injury.
Renal Ly6C hi inflammatory monocytes, monocyte-derived DCs, F4/80 þ macrophages, CD4 þ T cells, and neutrophils all increased with anti-MPO IgG treatment in WT mice.
More important, all of these cells, except the neutrophils, were diminished in the CCR2-DTR group that showed still similar nephritic urine abnormalities, but only minimal crescents and necrosis.
These data suggest that renal monocyte/macrophage signals were important for CD4 þ T-cell, but of minor significance for neutrophil, recruitment.
Monocyte effects on neutrophil recruitment may differ with the depletion strategy and disease model.

For example, clodronate liposomeemediated monocyte depletion reduced glomerular neutrophils in an antieglomerular basement membrane disease model, 30 whereas CCR2 deficiency reduced monocytes without affecting neutrophil influx into the inflamed tissue in a fungal infection model. 23

Furthermore, combining our data with the neutrophil depletion data from Xiao et al 31 suggests that neutrophils are necessary and also sufficient to induce structural changes within the capillary loops that result in albuminuria and nephritic sediment.
However, neutrophils alone are not sufficient for maximal glomerular necrosis and crescent formationdthe hallmark of ANCA-induced NCGN.

Monocytes are essential for extracapillary proliferation with crescent formation, and it is conceivable that even neutrophil and monocyte interactions, particularly with Ly6C lo monocytes, in the glomerular microvasculature are needed, as recently demonstrated in an antieglomerular basement membrane model. 30
he sCD163 scavenger receptor that is shed from activated monocytes and macrophages is currently evaluated as a biomarker in inflammatory conditions.
For example, serum sCD163 was increased in patients with diabetic complications, 32 whereas urine sCD163 was increased in AAV patients with renal manifestation and in a rat model. 28
n our 6-day model, serum sCD163, but not urinary sCD163, showed a strong increase with crescent formation, and monocyte depletion completely abolished this effect.
These observations underline the value of sCD163 as a monocyte/macrophage activation marker and suggest that the increase in serum precedes that in urine.
In fact, the rat AAV model used by O'Reilly et al 28 documented urinary sCD163 increase after 4 weeks, whereas serum levels were not reported.
Evaluating serum and urinary sCD163 in different models with standardized assays will help to understand the kinetics and significance of this biomarker.
It is conceivable that longer disease duration is needed for urinary sCD163 to increase.

div.formula: þ LyC hi monocytes, CD11b þ F4/80 þ macrophages, and CD11c þ MHCII þ dendritic cells (DCs) (A), CD11b þ Ly6G þ neutrophils (B), and CD4 þ T cells (C), respectively. The relative frequency of CD11b þ LyC hi monocytes, CD11b þ F4/80 þ macrophages, and CD11b þ Ly6G þ neutrophils was expressed as percentage of CD45 þ CD11b þ leukocytes, the CD11c þ MHCII þ DCs as per- centage of CD45 þ cells, and the CD4 þ T cells as percentage of CD45 þ CD3 þ cells,

p.s: Naturally, there are still open questions for future studies.
It will be interesting to learn which monocyte/macrophage subset and other nonparenchymal cells contribute to crescent formation in AAV models.
Ly6C hi inflammatory monocytes, together with neutrophils and CD4 þ type 17 helper T cells, provide certainly good candidates.

CD11c þ MHCII þ dendritic cells and F4/80 þ macrophages are potentially more important for antigen uptake and presentation, functions that are less significant in our short-term antibody transfer model.

Monocyte-derived cells mediate protective functions as CD103 þ DCs were recently shown to reduce crescent formation in an antieglomerular basement membrane model by inducing IL-10eproducing T regulatory cells. 33

Reparative and profibrotic processes (eg, by the newly characterized segregated-nucleusecontaining atypical monocyte subset) 34 are also conceivable, but are better addressed in long-term models by depletion at later time points after the glomerular damage is already established.

DT possibly induced direct depletion of a minor percentage of activated natural killer and CD4 þ T cells that expressed CCR2-DTR þ that may have provided additional protection from the disease (Supplemental Figure S1C).
In summary, our data suggest an important contribution of monocytes/macrophages to the development of glomerular crescents and necrosis in a renal AAV model.
Our findings provide a starting point and may facilitate future monocyte-related experiments in AAV.

Figure 2 Monocyte depletion protects from necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis induced by anti-MPO (a-MPO) IgG.
All analyses were performed at day 6.
A: Proteinuria (Prot), erythrocyturia (Ery), and leukocyturia (Leuk) by dipstick analysis.
B: Albuminuria by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.
C: Blood urea nitrogen (BUN).
D: Glomerular damage by histology and expressed as the mean percentage of glomeruli with crescents and necrosis, respectively.
E: Representative periodic acideSchiffestained images are shown.
Arrowheads indicate crescentic glomeruli.
Statistical significance was tested using oneway analysis of variance with Bonferroni multiple comparison test.
Data are expressed as means AE SEM.
Original magnification: Â20 (E, top row); Â40 (E, bottom row).
CCR2-DTR, CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor; WT, wild-type.
Figure 3 Monocyte depletion affects renal leukocyte infiltration in anti-MPO (a-MPO) IgG-induced necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis.
Renal leukocyte subsets were characterized by flow cytometry at day 6.

Typical flow cytometry experiments with relative cell frequencies and corresponding quantification of the absolute cell numbers per gram kidney weight are shown for renal inflammatory CD11bþ LyC hi monocytes, CD11b þ F4/80 þ macrophages, and CD11c þ MHCII þ dendritic cells (DCs) (A), CD11b þ Ly6G þ neutrophils (B), and CD4 þ T cells (C), respectively.

The relative frequency of CD11b þ LyC hi monocytes, CD11b þ F4/80 þ macrophages, and CD11b þ Ly6G þ neutrophils was expressed as percentage of CD45 þ CD11b þ leukocytes, the CD11c þ MHCII þ DCs as percentage of CD45 þ cells, and the CD4 þ T cells as percentage of CD45 þ CD3 þ cells,respectively.
Boxes and ovals indicate the cell population that is counted and named in each individual image.
Statistical significance was tested using one-way analysis of variance with Bonferroni multiple comparison test.
Data are expressed as means AE SEM.
CCR2-DTR, CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor; WT, wild-type.
respectively.
Boxes and ovals indicate the cell population that is counted and named in each individual image.
Statistical significance was tested using one-way analysis of variance with Bonferroni multiple comparison test.
Data are expressed as means AE SEM.
CCR2-DTR, CCR2 promoterecontrolled diphtheria toxin receptor; WT, wild-type.
We thank Sylvia Lucke, Susanne Rolle, and Tanja Filipowski for excellent technical assistance; and Dr. Tobias Hohl (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY) for CCR2-DTR mice.
Supplemental material for this article can be found at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ajpath.2017.05.003.
